\#\#\# User: I'm a math PhD who has been asked to interview a high school student and determine what he/she is interested in and how strong the student is.

Usually I would want them to talk as much as possible about what classes they've taken and what parts of the classes they like the best. Generally I'd like to allow them to get comfortable talking about what they like rather than what they think I'd like. However, that might not work this time as the student is a non\-native english speaker and may get less comfortable as I try to get him/her to talk more.

Thus far I'm thinking about watching how he/she solves different problems in different areas of math, but I would like to know if anyone has done this before or has any suggestions for evaluating a student who might not be comfortable talking much.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Well, I'm a non\-native English speaker, so I can provide some insight. 

I think that one of the first problems would be names and notation in general. As far as I can see, there is no easy way to solve this unless you already know the customs of the country the student is coming from, but your education will probably make it easier to guess what means what. For example in my country we use $log\_{base}number$ for general case logarithms, $lg$ for $log\_{10}$ and $ln$ for $log\_e$. Another example would be popular sets. In some countries 0 is a natural number and in some other countries it isn't. Another example would be popular trigonometric functions. In my country for example secant and cosecant are considered deprecated and aren't used. Same thing with grads as angle measurement units.

Problems with this part can be especially tricky because they can stay undetected for a long time. I've seen some math problems whose solutions depend on whether zero is a natural number or not. Another example here can be integrals. As far as I can see the most popular name in English for operation opposite of finding a derivative is antiderivation. In my area that's called indefinite integration and the indefinite part if often omitted.

Still I think that most of the notational problems can be solved with Wikipedia.

Next part would be names of fields of mathematics and popular theorems. How big problems this is going to be is closely related to which language terms come from. Sometimes terms are going to be shared between languages and sometimes there will be no direct translation. For example in my language, there is no term for calculus. Instead we use mathematical analysis, which as far as I know is superset of calculus.  

Also in some cultures some theorems are named after famous mathematicians and in some other cultures they are named after what the theorem describes. I can't find any examples right now, but I know I encountered such problems when asking few questions here. 

Another problem could be non\-existence of a concept. For example I was unable to find any mention of [Ivan Vsevolodovich Meshcherskiy's equation](http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=sr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fru.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2F%25D0%25A3%25D1%2580%25D0%25B0%25D0%25B2%25D0%25BD%25D0%25B5%25D0%25BD%25D0%25B8%25D0%25B5_%25D0%259C%25D0%25B5%25D1%2589%25D0%25B5%25D1%2580%25D1%2581%25D0%25BA%25D0%25BE%25D0%25B3%25D0%25BE) [(original article here](http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9C%D0%B5%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE)) for bodies with variable mass in any English language web\-sites. Here it's considered one of the fundamental rocketry equations, right next to Tsiolkovsky's formula. While the example is related more to physics than mathematics, be prepared to find similar examples in mathematics if the student is coming from a different culture.

Since you said that student knows some English, here's my recommendation: Try starting a conversation about some topic in English and see if student is familiar with it. If it doesn't ring a bell, be ready to provide simple examples related to the area. I sometimes had problems finding exact name for some field of mathematics but immediately recognized it as soon as I saw a few simple problems. Another good idea would be to make a list of alternative names for every operation and see if some of them are familiar.

Yet another important thing is to have at least some familiarity with mathematics program which the student followed. Sometimes focus of what's studied in classes can be a bit different than what's written on paper. I remember now back when I was in secondary school we had formal mathematical proofs in books and they were supposed to be a part of the curriculum, but teachers in schools just decided that proofs are not important and did not teach them. Also in some schools less attention was payed to proper use of terminology. I know some of my friends who didn't know what was derivative and it's graphical representations, but knew that $x^2{'}\=2x$ and same thing for integrals. Another point can be some obvious areas which may have been skipped. When was in secondary school, we didn't learn almost any probability and statistics and did very little work with percentages. On the other hand I see that in some other countries it's expected that someone who has graduated from primary school can without any problems calculate his interest rate.

I can't think of anything else to add at the moment...

\#\#\# User: ![The oscilloscope I will be using](https://i.stack.imgur.com/qjAq6.jpg)

At my university, I'll be using the ELENCO S\-1325 oscilloscope for a instrumentation lab. Since I'm a mechanical engineering student and not an electrical engineering one, I don't know exactly how to use all the functions though I am familiar with the basic use and operation of it. However, I want to know how to use some of the more complex functions of the oscilloscope.

On an oscilloscope, why would anyone move the variable knobs off their “calibrated” positions? the variable knobs (red VAR knob) for voltage measurements? the small gray “var sweep” knob for the time base?

Isn't it a good thing to keep things calibrated rather than use uncalibrated settings?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you want to measure the rise or fall time of a digital signal, you use the variable knob for voltage to adjust the amplitude, so that it fits between the horizontal dotted lines (5 divisions). Then you measure the time from 10% to 90% (the middle 4 divisions). Conveniently, there are even percent marks on the screen.

It's less common to use the horizontal variable adjust, maybe it could be used for measuring duty cycle.

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An engineer is using an oscilloscope to measure the rise time of a digital signal. Which of the following procedures correctly describes how to use the variable knob for voltage in this measurement?

A) Adjust the variable knob for voltage to increase the signal amplitude beyond the screen's vertical limits to ensure maximum accuracy.

B) Keep the variable knob for voltage in its calibrated position to maintain precise voltage measurements throughout the process.

C) Use the variable knob for voltage to adjust the signal amplitude so it fits exactly between the horizontal dotted lines (5 divisions) on the screen, then measure the time from 10% to 90% (middle 4 divisions).

D) Utilize the horizontal variable adjust knob instead of the voltage variable knob to properly measure the rise time of the digital signal.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct procedure for measuring rise time of a digital signal involves using the variable knob for voltage to adjust the signal amplitude to fit between the 5 divisions marked by horizontal dotted lines on the oscilloscope screen. This allows for easy measurement of the time from 10% to 90% of the signal's amplitude (corresponding to the middle 4 divisions). This method maximizes the use of the screen's vertical resolution and takes advantage of the percent marks often provided on oscilloscope screens, making the measurement more accurate and easier to perform.

Option A is incorrect because increasing amplitude beyond screen limits would make measurement impossible. Option B is incorrect because keeping the knob calibrated may not provide the optimal view for this specific measurement. Option D is incorrect because the horizontal variable adjust is not typically used for rise time measurements; it's the voltage (vertical) adjustment that's needed here.

\#\#\# User: The following is a question from the sample GRE Mathematics Subject Test
found on the ETS website:

Let $M$ be a $5\\times 5$ real matrix.
Exactly four of the following five conditions on $M$ are equivalent
to each other.
Which of the five conditions is equivalent to NONE of the other four?

(A) For any two distinct column vectors $u$ and $v$ of $M$,
the set {$u,v$} is linearly independent.

(B) The homogeneous system $Mx\=0$ has only the trivial solution.

(C) The system of equations $Mx\=b$ has a unique solution for each real $5\\times 1$
column vector $b$.

(D) The determinant of $M$ is nonzero.

(E) There exists a $5\\times 5$ real matrix $N$ such that $NM$ is the $5\\times 5$ identity matrix.

Apparently, the correct answer is (A), but I can't figure out why this is true. If $M$ is
nonsingular, as is implied by statements (B)\-(E), then isn't that equivalent to its column vectors being linearly
independent? And if the 5 column vectors are independent, then I can easily show that
each pair of vectors are independent. What am I missing?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Linear independence of $n$ vectors, for $n\>2$, is *not* equivalent to "pairwise" independence. Take three different vectors in the plane, for an example.

50.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the concept you described:

Question: Consider the following vectors in R^3:
v1 = (1, 0, 1)
v2 = (0, 1, 1)
v3 = (1, 1, 2)

Which of the following statements is true?

A) The set {v1, v2, v3} is linearly independent because each pair of vectors is linearly independent.

B) The set {v1, v2, v3} is linearly dependent, even though each pair of vectors is linearly independent.

C) If each pair of vectors is linearly independent, then the entire set must be linearly independent.

D) Linear independence of pairs of vectors has no bearing on the linear independence of the entire set.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: This question tests the understanding that pairwise independence does not guarantee linear independence of the entire set. In this case, v1, v2, and v3 are pairwise linearly independent, but the set {v1, v2, v3} is linearly dependent because v3 = v1 + v2. This illustrates that linear independence of n vectors (for n > 2) is not equivalent to pairwise independence. Option A is incorrect because it assumes pairwise independence implies independence of the set. Option C overgeneralizes this misconception. Option D is incorrect because pairwise independence is a necessary (but not sufficient) condition for the independence of the entire set.

\#\#\# User: I just started using Google Chrome, and tried to load Meta by typing "meta.stackoverflow.com" into the URL/search bar. I got as far as "met" before I noticed the following message on the right side of the bar:

> Press `Tab` to search Meta Stack Overflow

I did so, expecting to be taken to [the page I would have gotten](http://www.google.com/#hl=en&source=hp&q=site%3Ameta.stackoverflow.com+reasons+for+migrating&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai=&fp=1&cad=b) had I had gone to google.com and plugged in "site:meta.stackoverflow.com reasons for migrating"... but, no. Instead, I got taken to [Meta's own search page](https://meta.stackoverflow.com/search?q=reasons+for+migrating).

How is this possible? Does SO have some sort of backend widget that lets Google know what its internal search is? Did Google figure it out on its own? Is this normal for Chrome in general? Is there a formal/official name for this feature that I'm the last person on the planet to know about? Sorry about the vague title and question, but if I knew what this was called, I wouldn't really need to ask Meta about it in the first place.

RESOLUTION EDIT:  

It seems that the same feature kicks in when entering "site:meta.stackoverflow.com searchTerm1 searchTerm2" into the URL/search bar. Note that this means that searching for tags from Chrome **is supported**. This feature made possible by SO's and Chrome's mutual support of [OpenSearch](http://www.opensearch.org/Home) as described by bdonlan's and Justin's answers.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There's a tag in stackoverflow\-engine\-generated pages telling it to do that:

```
    <link rel="search" type="application/opensearchdescription+xml"
        title="Meta Stack Overflow" href="/content/mso/opensearch.xml"> 

```

The detailed spec can be found at the [opensearch homepage](http://www.opensearch.org/Home).

52.answer:
Here's a multi-part question based on the provided documentation:

Question: 
1. What technology enables the search functionality described in the StackExchange post?
2. How does Chrome know to search directly on Meta Stack Overflow when the user types "met" and presses Tab?
3. What is the significance of the <link> tag mentioned in the answer?
4. What would be a potential benefit of this feature for users?

A) 1. Google custom search
   2. Chrome has a predefined list of websites and their search capabilities
   3. It's a standard HTML tag for defining page metadata
   4. Faster access to Google search results for specific sites

B) 1. OpenSearch
   2. Meta Stack Overflow communicates this capability to Chrome
   3. It specifies the OpenSearch description for the site
   4. Direct access to the site's internal search from the browser's address bar

C) 1. StackExchange API
   2. Chrome detects the search box on the website automatically
   3. It's used for SEO optimization
   4. Improved ranking in Google search results

D) 1. Browser extension
   2. Users must install a Chrome extension for this functionality
   3. It loads a custom JavaScript file for search
   4. Ability to add custom search engines to Chrome

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
1. OpenSearch is the technology that enables this functionality, as mentioned in the resolution edit of the original post.
2. Meta Stack Overflow communicates its search capabilities to Chrome using the OpenSearch protocol, allowing Chrome to offer the Tab-to-search feature.
3. The <link> tag in the answer specifies the location of the OpenSearch description file for the site, which tells browsers how to use the site's search functionality.
4. This feature benefits users by providing direct access to the site's internal search function from the browser's address bar, saving time and streamlining the search process.

Option A is incorrect as it's not using Google custom search. Option C is wrong because it's not using the StackExchange API or automatically detecting the search box. Option D is incorrect as this functionality doesn't require a browser extension; it's built into Chrome and other browsers that support OpenSearch.

Does "sensitivity" need to be qualified, as in "sensitivity to touch"? Can someone point out the "rules" that come into play here?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is the following sentence grammatically correct?
> 
> 
> "Symptoms of lactic acid build up in muscles include cramps, spasms,
>  fatigue and sensitivity."

Yes, but you should change *build up* to *[buildup](http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/buildup)*.

> Does "sensitivity" need to be qualified, as in "sensitivity to touch"?

That wouldn't hurt (no pun intended), but it isn't necessary. You've established *muscles* as the subject.

> Can someone point out the "rules" that come into play here?

Regarding serial commas? You've broken no rules here.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following sentences about lactic acid buildup in muscles is most accurate and grammatically correct?

A) Symptoms of lactic acid build up in muscles include cramps, spasms, fatigue, and sensitivity to touch.

B) Symptoms of lactic acid buildup in muscles include cramps, spasms, fatigue and sensitivity.

C) Symptoms of lactic acid build-up in muscles include cramps, spasms, fatigue, and sensitivity.

D) Symptoms of lactic acid buildup in muscles include: cramps, spasms, fatigue, and sensitivity.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is the most accurate and grammatically correct sentence. Here's why:

1. It uses the correct term "buildup" as a single word, which is the proper noun form.
2. It doesn't require "sensitivity" to be qualified with "to touch" since the context of muscles has been established.
3. It correctly omits the serial (Oxford) comma before "and" in the list, which is a stylistic choice but not grammatically incorrect.
4. It doesn't use a hyphen in "buildup," which is the correct spelling.
5. It doesn't use a colon after "include," which isn't necessary in this context.

Options A and C use "build up" and "build-up" respectively, which are incorrect forms of the noun. Option D incorrectly uses a colon after "include." Option A adds "to touch," which isn't necessary given the context.

\#\#\# User: Suppose you're getting the latest version of a file from source control and a conflict occurs. There are four possible types of changes in the conflict:

1. Yours
2. Theirs
3. Both
4. Conflicting

Naturally, in cases 3 and 4 you'd want to review the changes manually (in the latter case you even have to resolve it). Regarding cases 1 and 2 I'm not sure, but I'm thinking only changes of type 2 (Theirs) should prompt manual inspection. The reason being, you know what you changed, as opposed to "their" changes which may break your changes. So I'm thinking one could skip reviewing his own changes (case 1\), and manually review / resolve the other changes (cases 2\-4\). 

Other developers suggested more extreme approaches \- such as only reviewing conflicting (or "both") changes and trusting automerge for the rest. The other extreme is reviewing all the changes every time.

Of course, other parameters may factor in. For example, if you only made a single correction to a file, and there are 200 changes made by others, then provided you can be reasonably sure that your change is unrelated (say it's an SQL file and you wrote a new separate stored procedure), perhaps you can skip reviewing the other changes.

I am torn between the dangers of not inspecting changes and the time and energy that could be saved by trusting the automatic merge. Supposedly, you have compilation and unit/component/e2e tests that will expose bad merges. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Supposedly, you have compilation and unit/component/e2e tests that will expose bad merges.

This is the important part to me. In general, I will trust the auto\-merge for code files (but not markup, project files, etc) where it can actually run (not conflicts). It tends to mangle projects and markup, but code files are (usually) fine.

But I also work in a place with frequent commits, good unit test coverage and gated check\-ins (if the build/tests don't succeed, the commit does not work). Oh, and my release date is months into the future, not hours... 95\+% of the time, it works just fine and I save the time and effort of looking through the merges. Different environments call for different carefulness.

55.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When merging changes from source control, which approach is generally considered safe and efficient for handling different types of changes, assuming you have a robust testing infrastructure in place?

A) Review all changes manually, regardless of their type or origin, to ensure maximum safety.

B) Only review conflicting changes (where both parties modified the same lines) and trust the auto-merge for all other types of changes.

C) Review "Their" changes and conflicting changes manually, but trust your own changes and auto-merged "Both" changes without review.

D) Trust the auto-merge for code files but manually review markup and project files, while relying on frequent commits, good unit test coverage, and gated check-ins to catch potential issues.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is the most balanced approach according to the top answer. It acknowledges that auto-merge is generally reliable for code files but may struggle with markup and project files. This approach saves time by trusting the auto-merge where it's most likely to succeed, while still exercising caution for file types prone to merge issues. The answer emphasizes the importance of having a strong testing infrastructure (frequent commits, good unit test coverage, and gated check-ins) to catch any problems that might slip through the auto-merge process. This strategy balances efficiency with safety, especially in environments where release dates are not imminent and there's time to address any issues that arise.

\#\#\# User: How does a phrase such as "Gag me with a spoon" originate? I understand the sentiment as a real concept — gagging oneself with a spoon causes a choking sensation without actually constricting breathing. It's uncomfortable and disconcerting. 

But, how did this become the go\-to dismissive phrase of the 80s?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The phrase "gag me with a spoon" originates from [Valley girl](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valley_girl) speak, which is in turn an obnoxious form of Californian english. From the wiki article:

> Valley Girl (or Val, Val Gal) is a stereotype leveled at a socio\-economic and ethnic class of American women who can be described as colloquial English\-speaking, materialistic, self\-centered, hedonistic, and often sexually promiscuous. Valspeak is also a form of this trait, based on an exaggerated version of '80s California English.

The phrase is used as an expression of disgust. A typical usage from the [online slang dictionary](http://onlineslangdictionary.com/meaning-of/gag-me-with-a-spoon)

> Oh my gosh, gag me with a spoon. That were the ugliest shoes I've ever seen!

The phrase also appears in Frank Zappa's song, [Valley girl](http://youtu.be/489pO9q8guA).

> .../Its like grody.../ Grody to the max/ Im sure/ Its like really nauseating/ Like barf out/ **Gag me with a spoon**/ Gross/ I am sure/ Totally...

---

As for the *how*, you could perhaps reason that the act of gagging yourself with a spoon is pretty disgusting and hence it makes sense. However, I'm not sure you should look for a reason/proper etymology for any of the valley girl\-isms (*ummm*, *like*, *totally*, *so bitchin'*, *whatever*, etc.).

56.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the origin and usage of the phrase "Gag me with a spoon"?

A) It originated from medical terminology and was adopted by teenagers in the 1990s to express excitement.

B) It was coined by Frank Zappa in his song "Valley Girl" and later became popular among the general public.

C) It emerged from Valley Girl speak in 1980s California and was used as an expression of disgust or distaste.

D) It was a common phrase used by English aristocrats in the 18th century to denote boredom at social gatherings.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The phrase "Gag me with a spoon" originated from Valley Girl speak, a form of California English associated with a stereotype of young, materialistic women in the 1980s. It was used as an expression of disgust or distaste, often in response to something considered unappealing or offensive. The phrase gained popularity as part of the broader Valley Girl culture and was featured in Frank Zappa's song "Valley Girl," but it wasn't coined by him. It's not related to medical terminology, 1990s teen culture, or 18th-century English aristocracy.

\#\#\# User: **Problem:** I have a query file that have a `@@procid` statement. I want to know the use and meaning of this. I'm new on this, sorry if it is silly.

**Question:** On my searches, on [this site](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms174408.aspx), I learned that it returns the procedure id of current Transact\-SQL module, but what is this? What does "Transact\-SQL module" mean? It should not return the remainder of some division([here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms190279.aspx))? I didn't get the example showed on that page. 

Or did I misunderstand this?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The @@procid is the identifier associated with the current executing stored procedure, trigger, or user defined function. It is an internal number sql server uses to keep track of these items in the system. So with this id you can look up what object is associated with it. So in the following example: 

`SET @ProcName = OBJECT_NAME(@@PROCID);`

Gets the procedure name, because OBJECT\_NAME is a function which gets the name from the `@@PROCID`. 

The example is a little contrived, because the question ultimately becomes 'why not just hard code the name?' The point of @@Proc is so that if you don't know what is executing (maybe dynamic code or such), you have a way of determining what is being executed at that point in time without having to hard code that information everywhere.

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements about @@PROCID in SQL Server is NOT correct?

A) It returns the identifier of the currently executing stored procedure, trigger, or user-defined function.
B) It can be used in combination with OBJECT_NAME() function to retrieve the name of the currently executing module.
C) It is primarily used for dynamic code execution scenarios where the executing module is not known in advance.
D) It returns the remainder of a division operation in Transact-SQL.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is correct: @@PROCID indeed returns the identifier of the currently executing Transact-SQL module (stored procedure, trigger, or user-defined function).
B is correct: As shown in the example, OBJECT_NAME(@@PROCID) can be used to get the name of the currently executing module.
C is correct: The main purpose of @@PROCID is to identify the currently executing module in scenarios where it's not known in advance, such as in dynamic code execution.
D is incorrect: This is a misunderstanding. @@PROCID does not return the remainder of a division operation. The confusion might arise from the similarity to the modulo operator (%), but @@PROCID is unrelated to mathematical operations.

The correct answer is D because it's the only statement that is not true about @@PROCID. The other options accurately describe the purpose and use of @@PROCID in SQL Server.

\#\#\# User: I need an external SSD with Kubuntu to boot on different computers. So I created LiveCD, booted from it, plugged external SSD. 

With the help of GParted I converted the SSD to GPT and created partitions. Then I started installation as usual. Of course, I used the EFI partition and installed the bootloader on an external SSD.

After installation, and upon rebooting, in the UEFI I found 2 boot entries "Ubuntu". Each of them works great: Kubuntu loads and works. But, when I choose UEFI boot entry "UEFI TS512\..." (the label of my external SSD), for a moment (less than second) the string `Couldn't open /EFI/BOOT/fallback.efi 14` appears and then it changes to a screen showing `Minimal BASH-like line editing is supported`. 

So, what do I need to do in order to make this system work?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your SSD is considered "removable media" by UEFI, so the place for the bootloader which UEFI runs is actually /EFI/Boot/bootx64\.efi from the SSD's EFI partition. You might have to copy the Ubuntu bootloader(s) from /EFI/ubuntu there and rename them to bootx64\.efi. If you are running secure boot, copy /EFI/ubuntu/shimx64\.efi to /EFI/Boot/bootx64\.efi and also copy /EFI/ubuntu/grubx64\.efi to /EFI/Boot/grubx64\.efi (that's the signed version). Without secure boot, just copy /EFI/ubuntu/grubx64\.efi to /EFI/Boot/bootx64\.efi (the unsigned version). The grub.cfg file should be in /EFI/ubuntu/grub.cfg (and that should be just a 3 liner which brings in the maintained grub.cfg from the regular /boot/grub location.

---

The removable media's EFI partition is set up just like the hard disk's EFI. FAT filesystem, flagged bootable, (and created with the efi type, "ef", check the type list, might have zeros too in some tools). Look at the live install media, it meets the criteria. (FAT filesystem, flagged bootable, directory /EFI/Boot, efi bootloader).

---

With the SSD booting alone, you might have to edit the grub.cfg files after you add two hard disks. The two grub.cfg files are in (EFI partition)/EFI/ubuntu.grub.cfg (a three liner) and /boot/grub/grub.cfg (the full config file). Change any hd0 references to hd2 (assuming the hard disks now get 0 and 1\), and if you see any /dev/sda references, change those to /dev/sdc... USB is set to first place in the UEFI boot settings, right? When you invoke the efi boot menu (some function key at power on probably), is USB first? When you select USB, does it try to boot from the SSD?

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: When creating a bootable external SSD with Kubuntu for use on different computers, which of the following steps is crucial to ensure proper booting on UEFI systems that treat the SSD as removable media?

A) Install the bootloader only to the EFI partition of the external SSD
B) Copy the Ubuntu bootloader from /EFI/ubuntu to /EFI/Boot and rename it to bootx64.efi
C) Convert the SSD to MBR instead of GPT
D) Create multiple boot entries labeled "Ubuntu" in the UEFI settings

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. When an external SSD is treated as removable media by UEFI systems, the bootloader needs to be in a specific location: /EFI/Boot/bootx64.efi on the SSD's EFI partition. Simply installing the bootloader to the EFI partition (option A) is not sufficient, as UEFI looks for a specific file name and location for removable media. 

Option C is incorrect because GPT is preferred for UEFI systems, and converting to MBR would not solve the bootloader location issue. Option D is also incorrect, as creating multiple boot entries doesn't address the core problem of the bootloader's location.

The correct procedure involves copying the Ubuntu bootloader (either shimx64.efi for Secure Boot or grubx64.efi for non-Secure Boot) from /EFI/ubuntu to /EFI/Boot and renaming it to bootx64.efi. This ensures that UEFI systems can find and execute the bootloader correctly when treating the SSD as removable media.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Opera browser's Unite feature was discontinued after version 11. A user wants to continue using Unite while also having access to newer Opera versions on Ubuntu. Which of the following approaches would best achieve this goal?

A) Install Opera 12 and enable the Unite feature in its settings
B) Download and install Opera 11.64, then install the latest stable version of Opera 12 or higher
C) Download and install Opera 11.64, then install the latest alpha, beta, or nightly build of Opera
D) Use a Windows virtual machine to run Opera 11 with Unite alongside the latest Opera version for Ubuntu

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct approach is to install Opera 11.64, which includes the Unite feature, and then install a bleeding-edge version (alpha, beta, or nightly build) of Opera. This allows the user to have both Opera 11 with Unite and a newer version of Opera running simultaneously on Ubuntu.

Option A is incorrect because Unite is not available in Opera 12 and cannot be enabled in settings.

Option B is incorrect because installing two stable versions of Opera (11.64 and 12 or higher) would likely cause conflicts and may not allow both to run simultaneously.

Option D is incorrect because it introduces unnecessary complexity by requiring a Windows virtual machine, when the goal can be achieved directly on Ubuntu.

The documentation specifically notes that to use both Opera 11 and a later build simultaneously, one of them should be an alpha, beta, or nightly build, which is precisely what option C suggests.
